comments.author: alessandra@clear.net.nz
comments.content:
Good! I never thought of making gomashio, but now I will, thank you!

XX
A.

comments.author: joyce
comments.content: i haven't thought about gomashio or my mom's suribachi in a long time! now i think in need to get both!! thanks, as always michael for a terrific post!

comments.author: Lauren
comments.content: I adore gomashio! It's obviously great with Asian food, but we like to use it as a substitute for salt to season a variety of other cuisines as well.

comments.author: Cajun Chef Ryan
comments.content: A great way to add good flavor to any dish.

comments.author: Carolyn Jung
comments.content: I'm going to have to try this, as I love sesame seeds, especially in cookies. I bet the gomashio would add a beguiling flavor to most any savory dish.

comments.author: Janna
comments.content: This reminds me of one of my favorite, easy-to-make meals when I don't want anything fancy:  rice, veggies, a fried egg, and kecap manis.  Next time I'll substitute gomashio for the sweet n' salty kecap manis.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: @janna - funny you mention that, because I almost glazed the tofu with kecap manis instead of hoisin... love that stuff.

comments.author: thepinkpeppercorn
comments.content: Oddly enough, I've been meaning to make this for a long time.  I had better get on it!

comments.author: Kim, Rambling Family Manager
comments.content: If someone sat that dish from the picture in front of me it would be GONE in mere seconds. :) I haven't worked with tofu much at all; how do you make the hoisin glazed tofu??

comments.author: deanne
comments.content: Recipe worked really well, I noticed the store bought ones here in Australia all have MSG in it so was pleased that it is so easy to DIY
